awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: REU Site: Multisite REU in Synthetic Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative REU site award to Simmons University, located in Boston, MA, and North Carolina A&T State University, located in Greensboro, NC, will support the training of 12 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019- 2021. This is a multisite REU collaborative and each site will host 6 students each summer. The focus of the program is to provide research experiences in the multidisciplinary field of Synthetic Biology, an emerging field of biology that integrates multiple scientific disciplines, including biology, mathematics, chemistry, and computer science.  Faculty mentors will be drawn from the Departments of Chemistry, Biology, Mathematics, and Computer Science at both institutions. During the 10-week program, students will be engaged in synthetic biology research projects that teach them how to 1) use synthetic biology strategies to solve complex biological problems, 2) work in a multidisciplinary research team, and 3) develop cross-disciplinary communication skills. A common week-long boot camp will be incorporated at both institutions using shared modules to articulate common objectives, laboratory techniques, and computational skills.  To foster the collaboration between the sites, paired virtual research groups will be created between sites and joint programming in STEM career planning will be delivered using a variety of social media platforms. The online learning community will consist of weekly cohort meetings via webinar and a virtual journal club led by students and facilitated by faculty mentors. During the program, students will also participate in a series of workshops focused on core synthetic biology techniques, bioethical issues associated with synthetic biology, implicit bias and sexual harassment in STEM, and careers in STEM. The summer program will culminate with a consortium-wide virtual symposium where students will have the opportunity to present their research to their colleagues and receive constructive feedback.  Students will be selected based on their interest in research, academic record, recommendation letters from their home institutions and phone interviews with faculty mentors on the selection committee. 

It is anticipated that a total of 36 students, primarily from underrepresented minority groups and from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program.  Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences.  This program is designed for students interested in pursuing research careers in STEM fields. 

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program.  Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting or by contacting the PI (Dr. Jennifer Roecklein-Canfield at Jennifer.canfield@simmons.edu)  or the co-PI (Dr. Mariam Ismail at Mariam.ismail@simmons.edu) at Simmons University or the PI (Dr. Robert Newman at rhnewman@ncat.edu) at North Carolina A&T State University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the project period from 2019-2023, we successfully launched our Multisite Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) in Synthetic Biology program. The program, which is a collaboration between North Carolina A&T State University (NC A&T) and Simmons University, provided integrated synthetic biology research experiences for undergraduate students from institutions across the country. At NC A&T, students worked together in interdisciplinary teams on various projects related to synthetic biology. For instance, students majoring in disciplines ranging from Biology and Biochemistry to Biophysics, Mathematics, and Computer Science worked together to design and synthesize molecular tools, such as genetically encodable fluorescent biosensors and chemically inducible signaling enzymes, that are able to track and modulate signaling processes inside cells with high spatial and temporal resolution. Meanwhile, other groups of students helped design DNA-based “robots” and designer exosomes for targeted delivery of molecular cargos to cells and to reengineer the genomes of bacterial viruses. Likewise, another group of students used computational modeling and molecular dynamics simulations to design and test synthetic collagen that can be used for various applications, ranging from knee replacements to biocompatible coatings. Importantly, the interdisciplinary pairings helped students learn to communicate across disciplines while gaining a greater appreciation for the role of collaboration and interdisciplinary thinking in modern bioscience research.

A key aspect of our Collaborative REU was the virtual collaboration between REU students at NC A&T and those at Simmons University in Boston, MA. This included virtual lab meetings, research updates, and career development activities (e.g., a “Navigating Graduate School Admissions” panel discussion with the several Graduate Program Directors, and a Graduate Student Panel designed to give the students the “Inside Scoop on Graduate School”). In addition to graduate students at NC A&T, the panel also included several alumni of our REU program who have recently begun Ph.D. programs. In addition, students engaged in a series of virtual workshops focused on programming (i.e., coding in Python), bioethics (e.g., bioethical considerations in synthetic biology) and scientific communication (e.g., scientific writing, how to deliver an elevator talk, and how to construct an attention-grabbing poster). The students also led a virtual journal club where each team presented a primary journal article related to their project. On the off weeks, one of the research mentors gave a short overview of her/his research and entertained questions from the students about their research journey. As a culminating experience, each team summarized their projects in a journal-style report and presented their research findings to their fellow researchers at NC A&T and Simmons University during a virtual poster presentation between the sites. Likewise, each of the students at NC A&T presented physical posters at the Undergraduate Research Symposia at the NC A&T/UNCG Joint School of Nanoscience and Nanoengineering (JSNN).

Our REU program has been particularly effective at mentoring underrepresented minority students. For instance, the percentage of participants from underrepresented minority (URM) groups was above 70% each year of the program, with a four-year average of 76.9%. In particular, the program has provided research experiences for African American (AA; 65.4%) and Latinx (11.5%) students. Likewise, first generation college students were well represented in our cohorts, with 30.8% of the students being a part of this group. Importantly, based on evaluation data, our program has positively impacted the students’ scientific self-efficacy and desire to pursue research careers in STEM fields, particularly among URM students. For instance, among the twenty-six (26) undergraduate students who participated in our program, twenty (20) students were from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM. Among the eighteen (18) students who have graduated to date, fifteen (15; 83.4%) are pursuing graduate degrees, with 10 students (55.6%) pursuing PhDs and the remaining 5 (27.8%) pursuing MS degrees. Likewise, one REU student is currently enrolled in medical school while two students are pursuing careers in the bioscience workforce. By providing research experiences for undergraduate students, a large proportion of whom are from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM, our program has the potential to help increase the diversity of the STEM workforce.
